name: Universe, creation
description: Use this domain for general words referring to the physical universe. Some languages may not have a single word for the universe and may have to use a phrase such as 'rain, soil, and things of the sky' or 'sky, land, and water' or a descriptive phrase such as 'everything you can see' or 'everything that exists'.

subdomains.name: Sky
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the sky.

subdomains.name: Sun
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the sun. The sun does three basic things. It moves, it gives light, and it gives heat. These three actions are involved in the meanings of most of the words in this domain. Since the sun moves below the horizon, many words refer to it setting or rising. Since the sun is above the clouds, many words refer to it moving behind the clouds and the clouds blocking its light. The sun's light and heat also produce secondary effects. The sun causes plants to grow, and it causes damage to things.

subdomains.name: Moon
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the moon. In your culture people may believe things about the moon. For instance in European culture people used to believe that the moon caused people to become crazy. So in English we have words like "moon-struck" and "lunatic." You should include such words in this domain.

subdomains.name: Star
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the stars and other heavenly bodies.

subdomains.name: Planet
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to planets (large objects that circle the sun, looking like bright wandering stars in the sky), comets (objects that circle the sun, looking like a star with a tail), meteors (small objects that come from space and burn up when they hit the earth's atmosphere, causing a streak of light across the sky), and asteroids (small objects that circle the sun), planetary moons (large objects that circle the planets). Some cultures do not study the stars and will have few or no words in this domain. Others cultures that study the stars will have many words. There are only five planets that people can see in the sky--Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. The others are only known from the scientific study of astronomy.

subdomains.name: Air
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the air around us, including the air we breathe and the atmosphere around the earth.

subdomains.name: Blow air
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to causing air to move.

subdomains.name: Weather
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the weather.

subdomains.name: Wind
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the wind. Some words refer to when the wind begins and ends. The wind changes in speed, so some words refer to how fast the wind is moving. Try to rank these on a scale from very slow to very fast. These words may also be distinguished by what the wind does, since a fast wind does more things. These words may also be distinguished by how long the wind blows. Some words refer to the speed of the wind becoming faster or slower. Some words distinguish a steady wind from a wind in which the speed keeps changing. Some words refer to when the speed of the wind becomes faster for a short time. A steady wind moves in a particular direction, so there are words that include the direction of the wind. The direction of the wind may refer to the points of the compass, a neighboring geographical feature or area, or the direction in which the speaker is moving. Some words refer to a wind that moves in a small circle, making a pillar of dust or a funnel-shaped cloud. Some words refer to what the wind does, such as when it moves or damages something. People can feel the wind, so some words refer to how it feels. The wind makes noise, so there are words that refer to the sound of the wind. In some cultures there is a relation between the wind and spirits, so some words may refer to the activity of the spirits in the wind, or that the wind brings disease.

subdomains.name: Cloud
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the clouds.

subdomains.name: Rain
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the rain.

subdomains.name: Snow, ice
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to snow, ice, sleet, and hail.

subdomains.name: Storm
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to storms.

subdomains.name: Lightning, thunder
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to lightning and thunder.

subdomains.name: Flood
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to floods.

subdomains.name: Drought
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to drought.

subdomains.name: World
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the planet we live on.

subdomains.name: Land
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the ground we stand on, the earth versus the sky.

subdomains.name: Mountain
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to mountains.

subdomains.name: Volcano
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to volcanoes.

subdomains.name: Plain, plateau
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to land that is flat.

subdomains.name: Valley
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to valleys.

subdomains.name: Underground
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the area under the ground, and to holes in the ground.

subdomains.name: Forest, grassland, desert
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to an area of land that has particular types of plants growing in it.

subdomains.name: Earthquake
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to earthquakes. In some languages earthquakes are thought of as moving somewhere. In Amele (PNG) they say "mim nen" which means 'the earthquake came down (from above)'. In Northern Embera an earthquake is a "house-shaking". They say "a house-shaking went."

subdomains.name: Substance, matter
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to matter--what something is made out of, or a type of solid, liquid, or gas.

subdomains.name: Soil, dirt
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to soil and dirt.

subdomains.name: Rock
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to rock.

subdomains.name: Metal
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to metal.

subdomains.name: Mineral
subdomains.description: Use this domain for naturally occurring elements, compounds, and minerals--things you can find in the ground.

subdomains.name: Jewel
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to jewels and precious stones.

subdomains.name: Solid, liquid, gas
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing the different states of matter (solid, liquid, and gas), and words for changing from one to another.

subdomains.name: Liquid
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to liquids.

subdomains.name: Oil
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to oil.

subdomains.name: Gas
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to gas.

subdomains.name: Water
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to water.

subdomains.name: Bodies of water
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to bodies of water.

subdomains.name: Ocean, lake
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to bodies of standing water.

subdomains.name: Swamp
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to bodies of standing water with plants growing in them.

subdomains.name: River
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to bodies of flowing water.

subdomains.name: Spring, well
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a place where water comes out of the ground.

subdomains.name: Island, shore
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to land in contrast with the sea or river.

subdomains.name: Movement of water
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the way in which water and other liquids move.

subdomains.name: Flow
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the way water moves over a surface, such as in a river or along the ground.

subdomains.name: Pour
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to water coming out of something (such as a container), or causing water to come out of something.

subdomains.name: Drip
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to drops of water and what they do.

subdomains.name: Wave
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to waves and what they do.

subdomains.name: Calm, rough
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing the surface of water.

subdomains.name: Tide
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the tide.

subdomains.name: Wet
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to when something has water on it or water has soaked into it.

subdomains.name: Dry
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something that is dry.

subdomains.name: Be in water
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to being in water or putting something in water.

subdomains.name: Solutions of water
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a mixture of water and a substance (such as salt or sugar) that dissolves in water.

subdomains.name: Water quality
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing the quality or condition of water.

subdomains.name: Living things
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words that relate to all living things.

subdomains.name: Dead things
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to dead things--things that were alive before, but aren't now.

subdomains.name: Spirits of things
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the spirits of things.

subdomains.name: Plant
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words for all plants. Use a book of pictures to identify plant names and the scientific name. Languages divide plants into various domains that are not always comparable from language to language. Criterial features may be characteristics (trees and bushes are distinguished by size and number of trunks) and use (grass and weeds are distinguished by their desirability). A common distinction is between trees and non-trees, with trees described as being big, woody, and having a life expectancy of several years, while non-trees are small, non-woody, and have a life expectancy of typically not more than one year (Heine, Bernd and Karsten Legere. 1995. Swahili plants. Rudiger Koppe Verlag: Koln.). Agricultural societies will divide plants into wild and cultivated. However most plants for which there are names have some use. Therefore it does not seem helpful to divide plant names into domains for useful and non-useful plants. Since only parts of plants are eaten, edible parts of plants are listed under the domain 'Food'. Some languages may have more domains than are used in this list, others may have fewer. The classification system used here does not agree entirely with the system used by botanists. For instance botanists do not classify all the tree species together. The palm trees belong to the class Monocotyledoneae and are classified with lilies, bananas, and orchids. Apple and cherry trees belong to the class Dicotyledoneae and are classified in the rose family along with roses and blackberries. The acacia tree also belongs to the class Dicotyledoneae and is classified in the pulse family along with lupines and beans. However most folk taxonomies bring all the trees together. The scientific classification system for plants and animals is taken from: Carruth, Gorton, ed. 1989. The Volume Library, Vols. 1 and 2. The Southwestern Company: Nashville.

subdomains.name: Tree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for trees--flowering plants with roots, stems, and leaves, which are large and have a wooden trunk (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae). Also include the evergreen trees (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Gymnospermae). Evergreen trees do not have flowers, but have cone like fruits (pinecones) that contain seeds. Their leaves are shaped like needles and are retained for over a year.

subdomains.name: Bush, shrub
subdomains.description: Use this domain for bushes and shrubs--plants that are smaller than trees and have several wooden trunks (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae).

subdomains.name: Grass, herb, vine
subdomains.description: Use this domain for small plants that have roots, stems, flowers, and seeds, but do not have a wooden trunk (Phylum Spermatophyta, Subdivision Angiospermae). Also include the seedless plants, such as ferns (phylum Pteridophyta, class Felicineae), horsetails (phylum Pteridophyta, class Equisetineae), and club mosses (phylum Pteridophyta, class Lycopodineae). Plants of the Pteridophyta phylum have no flowers or seeds. Ferns have large, divided, feather-like leaves, or fronds. Club mosses are small (rarely over one meter) evergreen plants with simple leaves resembling pine or hemlock needles. Sometimes they grow upright, but often trail on the ground, where they propagate by means of runners. Horsetails send up tall, vertical, jointed stalks with branches covered with scale like leaves.

subdomains.name: Moss, fungus, algae
subdomains.description: Use this domain for mosses (phylum Bryophyta, class Musci), liverworts (phylum Bryophyta, class Hepaticae), fungi (phylum Thallophyta, subdivision Fungi), algae (phylum Thallophyta, subdivision Algae), and lichens. These plants do not have true roots, stems, or leaves. The mosses are small, green, flowerless plants that grow in moist environments and look like velvety or feathery growths carpeting the ground, tree trunks, and rocks. The liverworts are similar to the mosses with a flat and branching growth pattern. The algae possess green chlorophyll. They vary from one-celled organisms, which sometimes live in colonies such as pond scum, to complex organisms such as seaweed. The fungi do not possess chlorophyll and feed off of other organic material. Lichens consist of a fungus and an algae growing together. They commonly grow on trunks of trees and rocks. Some are flat and leafy, and some are moss like.

subdomains.name: Parts of a plant
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to parts of a plant. Start with general words that all plants have. Then think through each major type of plant. Finish by thinking of specific plants that are well known (usually cultivated crops) and that have words for specific parts (e.g. tassel on a corn/maize cob).

subdomains.name: Growth of plants
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the growth of plants.

subdomains.name: Plant diseases
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to plant diseases.

subdomains.name: Animal
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to animals.

subdomains.name: Types of animals
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing types of animals. Use a book of pictures to identify each species and its scientific name. This section is organized according to the scientific, biological classification of animals. It may not correspond to the local classification of animals (folk taxonomy), which are often based on how people relate to animals (tame/wild, edible/work). Use this domain for words referring to large classes of animals that do not correspond to the scientific classification. For instance this would be the place for a word like 'flying animal', which includes birds, bats, and flying insects.

subdomains.name: Mammal
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to mammals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia).

subdomains.name: Primate
subdomains.description: Use this domain for primates (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Primates).

subdomains.name: Carnivore
subdomains.description: Use this domain for carnivores--meat-eating animals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Carnivora).

subdomains.name: Hoofed animals
subdomains.description: Use this domain for even-toed hoofed animals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Artiodactyla), odd-toed hoofed animals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Perissodactyla), and elephants (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Proboscidea).

subdomains.name: Rodent
subdomains.description: Use this domain for rodents--gnawing animals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Rodentia), insect eating animals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Insectivora), rabbits (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Lagomorpha), and hyraxes (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Hyracoidea).

subdomains.name: Marsupial
subdomains.description: Use this domain for marsupials (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Marsupialia). Marsupials carry their young in a pouch.

subdomains.name: Anteater, aardvark
subdomains.description: Use this domain for mammals with few or no teeth--anteaters (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Edentata), pangolins (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Pholidota), aardvarks (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Tubulidentata), and platypus--mammals that lay eggs (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Monotremata).

subdomains.name: Sea mammal
subdomains.description: Use this domain for mammals that live in the sea--whales and dolphins (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Cetacea), seals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Pinnipedia), and sea cows (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Sirenia).

subdomains.name: Bat
subdomains.description: Use this domain for bats--flying mammals (phylum Chordata, class Mammalia, order Chiroptera).

subdomains.name: Bird
subdomains.description: Use this domain for birds (phylum Chordata, class Aves).

subdomains.name: Reptile
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to reptiles (phylum Chordata, class Reptilia).

subdomains.name: Snake
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to snakes.

subdomains.name: Lizard
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to lizards.

subdomains.name: Turtle
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to turtles.

subdomains.name: Crocodile
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to crocodiles.

subdomains.name: Amphibian
subdomains.description: Use this domain for amphibians (phylum Chordata, class Amphibia).

subdomains.name: Fish
subdomains.description: Use this domain for fish (phylum Chordata, class Osteichthyes).

subdomains.name: Shark, ray
subdomains.description: Use this domain for sharks and rays--animals with cartilage instead of bones (phylum Chordata, class Chondrichthyes), and eels (phylum Chordata, class Cyclostomata).

subdomains.name: Insect
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the names of insect species (phylum Arthropoda, class Insecta). Note that insects have six legs and spiders have eight legs. However some languages may not distinguish insects from spiders and may use other characteristics to sub-divide the Arthropods.

subdomains.name: Spider
subdomains.description: Use this domain for spiders (phylum Arthropoda, class Arachnida). Note that insects have six legs and spiders have eight legs. However some languages may not distinguish insects from spiders and may use other characteristics to sub-divide the Arthropods.

subdomains.name: Small animals
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the names of worms, animals with shells, and other animals that do not fit into any of the other categories.

subdomains.name: Parts of an animal
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of animals, especially those of mammals.

subdomains.name: Parts of a bird
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of a bird, but not general parts that belong to all animals.

subdomains.name: Parts of a reptile
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of a reptile.

subdomains.name: Parts of a fish
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of a fish.

subdomains.name: Parts of an insect
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of an insect.

subdomains.name: Parts of small animals
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of small animals.

subdomains.name: Animal life cycle
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the life cycle of an animal.

subdomains.name: Egg
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to eggs.

subdomains.name: Animal actions
subdomains.description: Use this domain for actions of animals.

subdomains.name: Animal movement
subdomains.description: Use this domain for ways in which animals move. Only include words specific for the movement of animals. For the movement of people use the domains under Movement. It is necessary to think through how each type of animal moves, especially the important ones.

subdomains.name: Animal eating
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to animals eating. Because animals often eat in very different ways from people, many languages will have words that are specific to the way an animal eats.

subdomains.name: Animal sounds
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the sounds animals make. It is necessary to think through the sounds each type of animal makes, especially the important ones.

subdomains.name: Animal home
subdomains.description: Use this domain for animal homes. It is necessary to think through the homes of each type of animal, especially the important ones.

subdomains.name: Animal group
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to groups of animals.

subdomains.name: Male and female animals
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to male and female animals. Most languages have special words for the male and female of a species only for domesticated animals. Sometimes there will be a word for the male and not the female, and vice versa (male dog, bitch). Sometimes the word for one is also used generically (cow for both female and generic).

subdomains.name: Nature, environment
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to nature and the environment--the world around us. Include words that refer to how people damage or protect nature.

subdomains.name: Natural
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something that is natural--something in the world around us, as opposed to something that has been made or changed by people.

name: Person
description: Use this domain for general words for a person or all mankind.

subdomains.name: Body
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words for the whole human body, and general words for any part of the body. Use a drawing or photo to label each part. Some words may be more general than others are and include some of the other words. For instance 'head' is more general than 'face' or 'nose'. Be sure that both general and specific parts are labeled.

subdomains.name: Head
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of the head.

subdomains.name: Eye
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the eye.

subdomains.name: Ear
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the ear.

subdomains.name: Nose
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the nose.

subdomains.name: Mouth
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the mouth. Do not use this domain for words referring to eating, drinking, or speaking.

subdomains.name: Tooth
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the teeth.

subdomains.name: Torso
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of the torso.

subdomains.name: Limb
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a limb--either an arm or a leg.

subdomains.name: Arm
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of the arm.

subdomains.name: Leg
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the parts of the leg and foot.

subdomains.name: Finger, toe
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the fingers and toes.

subdomains.name: Skin
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the skin.

subdomains.name: Hair
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to hair.

subdomains.name: Bone, joint
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the bones and joints.

subdomains.name: Flesh
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the soft tissue of the body.

subdomains.name: Internal organs
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the internal organs.

subdomains.name: Heart
subdomains.description: Use this domain for functions of the heart and blood veins.

subdomains.name: Stomach
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the stomach and to the normal functions of the stomach. Do not use this domain for stomach illness.

subdomains.name: Male organs
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the male reproductive organs.

subdomains.name: Female organs
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the female reproductive organs and a woman's monthly menstrual cycle. Some of these terms may be taboo. Care must be exercised in which terms are included in the dictionary. A group of women should decide which terms are 'public' and can go in the dictionary, and which would be considered taboo, overly crude, or embarrassing. For example some societies have been afraid that their women will be taken advantage of if these terms are known.

subdomains.name: Body functions
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the functions and actions of the whole body. Use the subdomains in this section  for functions, actions, secretions, and products of various parts of the body. In each domain include any special words that are used of animals.

subdomains.name: Breathe, breath
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to breathing.

subdomains.name: Cough, sneeze
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to coughing, sneezing, and other actions of the mouth and nose.

subdomains.name: Spit, saliva
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to spitting.

subdomains.name: Mucus
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to mucus in the nose.

subdomains.name: Bleed, blood
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to blood and bleeding.

subdomains.name: Sweat
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to sweating.

subdomains.name: Urinate, urine
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to urination.

subdomains.name: Defecate, feces
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to defecation.

subdomains.name: Sense, perceive
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words related to all the senses--sight, hearing, smell, taste, and feeling. Some languages may not distinguish some of these senses, and some languages may have words for other senses. There are also other senses that animals have. If your language has words for other senses, include them here.

subdomains.name: See
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to seeing something (in general or without conscious choice).

subdomains.name: Look
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to looking at someone or something--to see something because you want to.

subdomains.name: Watch
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to watching someone or something--to look for some time at something that is happening because you are interested in it and want to know what is happening.

subdomains.name: Examine
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to examining--to look carefully at something because you want to learn something about it.

subdomains.name: Show, let someone see
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to showing something to someone so that they can see it--to cause someone to see something.

subdomains.name: Visible
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being able to see something--words that describe something that can be seen, something that cannot be seen, something that is easy to see, or something that is difficult to see.

subdomains.name: Appear
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something appearing (becoming visible) and disappearing (becoming invisible).

subdomains.name: Transparent
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that describe how well you can see through something.

subdomains.name: Reflect, mirror
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to reflecting light.

subdomains.name: Appearance
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to how something appears.

subdomains.name: Beautiful
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing someone or something that is beautiful--pleasing in appearance,.

subdomains.name: Ugly
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing someone or something that is ugly--not pleasing in appearance.

subdomains.name: Something used to see
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to glasses and other things people use to help them see.

subdomains.name: Hear
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to hearing something (in general or without conscious choice).

subdomains.name: Listen
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to listening--to deliberately hear something.

subdomains.name: Sound
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to sounds.

subdomains.name: Types of sounds
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to types of sounds.

subdomains.name: Loud
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that describe loud sounds.

subdomains.name: Quiet
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that describe quiet sounds.

subdomains.name: Taste
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to tasting something.

subdomains.name: Smell
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to smelling something.

subdomains.name: Sense of touch
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the sense of touch--to feel something with your skin, to feel hot or cold, to feel tired or rested.

subdomains.name: Comfortable
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to feeling comfortable--to feel good in your body because there is nothing around you that makes you feel bad. This includes comfortable clothes, chair, bed, temperature, or journey.

subdomains.name: Body condition
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words related to the condition of the body.

subdomains.name: Strong
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that related to being strong, such as being able to lift a heavy object or being able to work hard.

subdomains.name: Weak
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being weak.

subdomains.name: Energetic
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being energetic.

subdomains.name: Tired
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being tired.

subdomains.name: Rest
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to resting.

subdomains.name: Healthy
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to a person being healthy--not sick.

subdomains.name: Sick
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing a person who is sick.

subdomains.name: Recover from sickness
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to recovering from sickness or injury.

subdomains.name: Disease
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words for disease and for words referring to specific diseases.

subdomains.name: Malnutrition, starvation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to not having enough food.

subdomains.name: Skin disease
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to skin diseases such as leprosy, boils, and rashes.

subdomains.name: Stomach illness
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to stomach illness.

subdomains.name: Tooth decay
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to tooth decay.

subdomains.name: Injure
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to injuring someone.

subdomains.name: Amputate

subdomains.name: Be about, subject
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something (said, written, thought, or made) depicts or is about a subject, or that something is logically related to some topic. Also use this domain for words that mark the topic or subject of what is being thought about, talked about, or written about. Verbs of thinking, knowing, or speaking (including other types of expression) can take a 'topic' role. We can think of a 'topic' as the main idea. Use this domain also for the important thing in a picture.

subdomains.name: Obscenity
subdomains.description: Use this domain for obscene words related to sex, defecation, death, damnation, and other taboo or offensive subjects. It is important to check the appropriateness of including obscene words in the dictionary. It should be the choice of the speakers of the language whether a word should be included or excluded. Obscene words included in the dictionary should be clearly marked as such. Obscenity is often used to heighten the emotion of an expression, and is often used when someone is angry. Obscenity is often associated with sex or defecation. Cursing is often associated with God, religion, or the afterlife. Insults often involve equating a person with an animal that is associated with an undesirable characteristic, questioning someone's parentage/legitimacy, questioning someone's character, or questioning someone's intelligence/sanity.

subdomains.name: God
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to God--the supreme being in the universe. Each theological system will have different beliefs concerning the existence and nature of God. Our purpose here is to collect and define the terms used to refer to the supreme deity. If there is no such person in the theological system, then use this domain for other terms for the pantheon of gods, ultimate reality, nirvana, and similar concepts. However most theological systems, even atheism, have the concept of a supreme God and use words to refer to him.

Fictional beings are those that no one has ever believed in. An indication of whether most people believe in the supernatural being should be put in the definition.

subdomains.name: Naked
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being naked--not wearing any clothes, and for words referring to how a person feels about being naked. It is a part of universal human experience that people do not want to be naked. So there are words that refer to feeling bad if one does not have enough clothes on (shame). Other words refer to wanting to have enough clothes (modest). Other words refer to how people feel about other people who do not wear enough clothes (indecent).

name: Physical actions
description: Use this domain for general words for physical actions--moving yourself, moving things, and changing things.

subdomains.name: Posture
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words indicating the posture or stance of a person's body. Use the domains in this section for specific words for postures and for moving parts of the body. Many of these words have two meanings. One meaning is stative, indicating that the body is in a particular posture, but not moving. The other meaning is active, indicating that the person is moving his body into a particular posture. Some of these words can be used of animals or even things, if the things are perceived as being similar in posture to that of a human body.

subdomains.name: Stand
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to standing. The words in this domain may include whether the person is standing on one foot or two, whether the person's feet are together or placed apart, whether something is between the person's feet, how fast the person stands up.

subdomains.name: Sit
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to sitting and squatting.

subdomains.name: Lie down
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to lying down.

subdomains.name: Kneel
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to kneeling.

subdomains.name: Bow
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to bowing to someone--to face someone and lower your head or bend at the waist so that your upper body is lowered. The words in this domain should all be symbolic acts, that is, the culture assigns a meaning and significance to the physical action. Some cultures define it as a greeting, as an act of respect, or as an act of submission. For instance in ancient middle eastern culture bowing was an act of submission done in the presence of the king. Failure to bow was an act of rebellion punishable by death. In far eastern culture it is a greeting. In African culture it is an act of respect or done to welcome a visitor. Cultures define how a person is to bow, for instance how they are to hold their hands. A person may bow while standing, or may kneel, or even prostrate himself flat on his face. Whether both people bow is also significant. The depth of the bow can have significance. In Japan the person of lower social rank must bow deeper. In European culture a performer bows to acknowledge applause.

subdomains.name: Lean
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing a person who is leaning.

subdomains.name: Straight posture
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to straight posture--holding your body straight, stiff, or erect, rather than relaxed.

subdomains.name: Relaxed posture
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing a relaxed posture.

subdomains.name: Bend down
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to bending down--to bend your body so that it is closer to the ground (in order to see something, pick up something, or hide).

subdomains.name: Move a part of the body
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving various parts of the body.

subdomains.name: Move
subdomains.description: Use this domain for intransitive verbs of movement referring to moving your whole body to a different location. There are many components of meaning involved in verbs of movement. They can include a source location (from), a goal location (to), a path (along), manner (walk, run), speed (race, crawl), direction (forward, back, side, up, down, toward, away from), shape of the path (straight, curve, circle, angle), relationship to some object or objects (on, hang, against, between, across, through, into, out of, onto, off of, around), proximity (near, far), multiple movements (back and forth, return, bounce), inclusion with other objects or parts of objects (join, leave, collect, disperse, unite, separate), volition (go versus drift), intransitive versus transitive (move versus move something). Some verbs of movement do not involve moving from one place to another, but express bodily movement.

subdomains.name: Manner of movement
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to the way in which a person moves.

subdomains.name: Walk
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to walking--moving slowly using your legs.

subdomains.name: Run
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to running--moving fast on your legs.

subdomains.name: Crawl
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to crawling--moving on your hands and knees or on your stomach.

subdomains.name: Jump
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to jumping--moving your body off the ground by pushing hard with your legs.

subdomains.name: Move quickly
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving quickly or slowly.

subdomains.name: Move slowly
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving slowly.

subdomains.name: Wander
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to wandering--to move slowly without any purpose or goal.

subdomains.name: Graceful
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in a graceful manner.

subdomains.name: Clumsy
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in a clumsy manner.

subdomains.name: Walk with difficulty
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to walking with some difficulty such as stumbling--to miss your step because of hitting an object such as a stone, hole, or mud; staggering--to walk unsteadily because of weakness, illness, or drunkenness; or limping--to walk unevenly or with difficulty because of injury to a foot.

subdomains.name: Slip, slide
subdomains.description: Use this domain for moving across a smooth or lubricated surface.

subdomains.name: Steady, unsteady
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to balancing yourself or something--when someone or something is able stand or move without falling.

subdomains.name: Balance
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to balancing yourself or something--when someone or something is able stand or move without falling.

subdomains.name: Move noisily
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to making a noise while moving.

subdomains.name: Move in a direction
subdomains.description: Use the domains in this section for words referring to moving in a direction related to the orientation of the person's body (not in relation to the position of the destination).

subdomains.name: Move forward
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in a forward direction--in the same direction the person is facing.

subdomains.name: Move back
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in a backward direction--the person is facing one direction, but moving toward their back--to move in the opposite direction from the direction the person is facing.

subdomains.name: Move sideways
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in a sideways direction--the person is facing one direction, but moving toward their side.

subdomains.name: Move up
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in an upward direction or to moving to a higher place.

subdomains.name: Move down
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving in a downward direction or to moving to a lower place.

subdomains.name: Fall
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something falling--for something to move down under the influence of gravity.

subdomains.name: Turn
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to turning and changing the direction in which one is moving.

subdomains.name: Move in a circle
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to continually changing the direction you are facing in until you are once again facing in the same direction, e.g. moving in a circle, moving around something, or rotating.

subdomains.name: Move back and forth
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to moving back and forth.

subdomains.name: Move straight without turning
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving straight without changing direction.

subdomains.name: Move toward something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving toward, in the direction of, or near something or some place. The words in this domain should refer to moving in the direction of a place, but should not require that the person actually arrived. Some languages (such as German and Polish) distinguish 'go on foot' from 'go in a vehicle'.

subdomains.name: Move away
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving away from a place.

subdomains.name: Go
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving away from the speaker. In Australian languages many movement words are marked for direction toward or away from the speaker.

subdomains.name: Come
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving toward the speaker.

subdomains.name: Leave
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving away from a place.

subdomains.name: Arrive

subdomains.name: Move in
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to moving into something, such as a house or an area.

subdomains.name: Move out
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to moving out of something, such as a house or area.

subdomains.name: Move past, over, through

subdomains.name: Return
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to returning to a place--to go back to a place you earlier left.

subdomains.name: Travel

subdomains.name: Travel by water

subdomains.name: Swim

subdomains.name: Dive
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving under the water.

subdomains.name: Fly

subdomains.name: Travel in space

subdomains.name: Way, route

subdomains.name: Lose your way

subdomains.name: Map
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to a map--a drawing of the world or part of the world.

subdomains.name: Accompany
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving with someone.

subdomains.name: Move together

subdomains.name: Pursue

subdomains.name: Catch, capture

subdomains.name: Prevent from moving
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to preventing someone or something from moving.

subdomains.name: Escape

subdomains.name: Set free

subdomains.name: Not moving
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to not moving.

subdomains.name: Stop moving
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to stopping moving.

subdomains.name: Stay, remain

subdomains.name: Wait

The basic idea of waiting is for someone to not do anything for a period of time, because he expects something to happen that will cause him to do something.

subdomains.name: Send someone

subdomains.name: Move something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to moving something or someone.

subdomains.name: Carry
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to carrying something--to pick something up and hold it while moving oneself.

subdomains.name: Throw
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to throwing something.

subdomains.name: Catch
subdomains.description: Use this domain for verbs for catching something that is thrown or dropped

subdomains.name: Shake

subdomains.name: Knock over

subdomains.name: Set upright
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to setting something upright.

subdomains.name: Move something in a direction
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words related to moving something in a direction.

subdomains.name: Put in front

subdomains.name: Put in back
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to putting something in back of you or in back of something else.

subdomains.name: Lift
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to putting something above you or above something else, putting something on top of something else, or moving something higher than it was.

subdomains.name: Hang
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to hanging something, and for words describing something that has been hung.

subdomains.name: Lower something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to putting something lower than you or lower than something else, putting something under something else, or moving something lower than it was.

subdomains.name: Put in
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to putting something inside something else.

subdomains.name: Take something out of something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to taking something out of something else.

subdomains.name: Pull
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to pulling--causing something to move toward you.

subdomains.name: Push

subdomains.name: Take somewhere

subdomains.name: Take something from somewhere
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to taking something or someone from its place.

subdomains.name: Return something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving something back to an original place or person. (Something is in a place, someone (or something) moves it, then someone moves it back to the first place.)

subdomains.name: Send
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to sending something--to cause someone to take something somewhere.

subdomains.name: Chase away
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to chasing or driving people and animals--to cause someone (or an animal) to move.

subdomains.name: Drive along
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to driving people and animals--to cause someone (or an animal) to move with you.

subdomains.name: Handle something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words for using the hands to move something.

subdomains.name: Touch
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to touching something with your hand without moving the thing.

subdomains.name: Pick up
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to picking something up.

subdomains.name: Put down
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to putting something down.

subdomains.name: Hold
subdomains.description: Use this domain for holding something in the hand.

subdomains.name: Actions of the hand
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the functions and actions of the hand.

subdomains.name: Support
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to keeping something from falling.

subdomains.name: Extend
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to extending something--to move something so that it covers a greater distance or area.

subdomains.name: Turn something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for turning something--to cause something to change direction, or to cause something to revolve or move in a circle.

subdomains.name: Open
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to opening something.

subdomains.name: Shut, close
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to shutting something.

subdomains.name: Block, dam up
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to preventing someone or something from moving

subdomains.name: Limit
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a limit beyond which something may or should not go, and for words referring to imposing a limit.

subdomains.name: Cover
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to covering something.

subdomains.name: Uncover
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to uncovering something.

subdomains.name: Wrap
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to wrapping something--to cover something on all sides with something like leaves, cloth, or paper.

subdomains.name: Spread, smear
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to spreading something--to cover something on all sides with something liquid or sticky like paint or mud.

subdomains.name: Transport
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to moving something in a vehicle.

subdomains.name: Have, be with
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to having something.

subdomains.name: Give, hand to
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to giving something to someone, in which there is no transaction of ownership, merely the movement of the thing from one person to another.

subdomains.name: Receive
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to receiving something from someone.

subdomains.name: Get
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to getting something.

subdomains.name: Distribute
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to distributing things to several people.

subdomains.name: Keep something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to keeping something.

subdomains.name: Leave something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to leaving something or someone in a place and going away.

subdomains.name: Throw away
subdomains.description: Use this domain for throwing away something that you no longer want.

subdomains.name: Not have
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to having something.

subdomains.name: Arrange
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to arranging things--to physically move a group of things or people and put them in a pattern.

subdomains.name: Gather
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to gathering things into a group. The basic idea of this domain involves a situation in which two or more things are not together, and someone moves them so that they are together.

subdomains.name: Separate, scatter
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to separating things into groups, and scattering things. The basic idea of this domain involves a situation in which two or more things are together, and someone moves them so that they are no longer together.

subdomains.name: Include
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to including something in a group.

subdomains.name: Special
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that describe a member of a group that is different or special.

subdomains.name: Join, attach
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to joining two or more things together.

subdomains.name: Link, connect
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to a linking or connecting things together--to put something like a road, pipe, or wire between things so that people or things can move between them.

subdomains.name: Stick together
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to two or more things cohering or sticking together.

subdomains.name: Add to something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to adding something to another thing.

subdomains.name: Remove, take apart
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to removing part of something, taking something apart, and things coming apart.

subdomains.name: Mix
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to mixing things together--to put two or more different kinds of substances, like liquids or cooking ingredients,  together.

subdomains.name: Pure, unmixed
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being pure--words describing something (like water, food, or air) that does not have anything bad in it; or unmixed--words describing something that is only one thing and has not been mixed with something else.

subdomains.name: Tie
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to tying things together.

subdomains.name: Rope, string
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to rope, string, and other things used to tie things together.

subdomains.name: Tangle
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to becoming tangled--when something long and thin, such as rope, string, thread, hair, grass, or vines, becomes disorganized, twisted, or knotted, so that it is hard to separate it.

subdomains.name: Organize
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to organizing things, people, events, and ideas--to think about and decide on the pattern a group of things should be arranged in, and then doing whatever is necessary to arrange them so that they can be used for some purpose. This domain is like the domain 'Arrange' except that 'Arrange' emphasizes physically moving the things, and the domain 'Organize' emphasizes the logical system. 'Organize' does not require that the things be moved, only that the logical pattern is specified.

subdomains.name: Disorganized
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to things becoming disorganized.

subdomains.name: Substitute
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to substituting something for something else--to move something and put something else in its place.

subdomains.name: Multiple things moving
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to multiple things moving.

subdomains.name: Simple, complicated
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being simple or complicated--words describing the organization of a group of things.

subdomains.name: Put
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to putting something somewhere.

subdomains.name: Load, pile
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to putting lots of things on something.

subdomains.name: Fill, cover
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to filling a container or covering an area with something.

subdomains.name: Hide
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to hiding things so that they cannot be seen or found, and for hiding oneself.

subdomains.name: Search
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to searching for something that has been hidden or lost.

subdomains.name: Find

subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to making a physical impact on  something, including the words for the action itself and the result of the  action.

subdomains.name: Hit
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to hitting something.

subdomains.name: Aim at a target
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to aiming at a target, and for hitting or missing the target.

subdomains.name: Kick
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to kicking--to hit something with your foot. The words in this domain may be distinguished by the way in which the foot moves, either in a swinging motion, or by first bending the leg and then quickly straightening it. They may also be distinguished by whether the foot moves horizontally or vertically, whether the effect is to move something or damage it, or how hard the person kicks.

subdomains.name: Press
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to pressing something.

subdomains.name: Rub
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to rubbing--to move something smooth against something else, in order to make it smooth or clean.

subdomains.name: Grind
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to grinding--to rub something rough against something else, while applying force, in order to break it or remove its surface.

subdomains.name: Mark
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to making a mark on something.

subdomains.name: Divide into pieces
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to dividing something into parts or pieces, perhaps with the added idea of using care, or into a certain number of parts.

subdomains.name: Number

So we have included a separate domain for 'one' and 'two'. In addition the numbers form a series (one, two, three...). Most languages have more than one series of numbers (first, second, third...).  So we have also included a domain for each series of numbers that most languages have. Your language may have other series of numbers. Put them in the domain 'Number series'.

subdomains.name: Cardinal numbers
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the cardinal numbers (one, two, three)--the numbers used to count.

subdomains.name: One

subdomains.name: Two

subdomains.name: Ordinal numbers

subdomains.name: Number of times

subdomains.name: Multiples

subdomains.name: Numbered group

subdomains.name: Fraction

subdomains.name: Number series

Other languages, such as Austronesian languages, use a separate word. Some languages also have words or affixes that indicate that there are two of something.
