subdomains.name: Recently
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something happened recently--a short time before now.

subdomains.name: Present
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the present time.

subdomains.name: Now
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to now.

subdomains.name: Future
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the future.

subdomains.name: Soon
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening soon.

subdomains.name: Not yet
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something not happening yet.

subdomains.name: Eventually
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening eventually.

subdomains.name: Immediately
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening immediately--without any time passing before it happens.

subdomains.name: Age
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the age of something.

subdomains.name: Young
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something young--a word describing a living thing that has only existed for a short time.

subdomains.name: Old, not young
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something old--a word describing a living thing that has existed for a long time.

subdomains.name: New
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something new--a word describing something that has only existed for a short time.

subdomains.name: Old, not new
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something old--a word describing something that has existed for a long time.

subdomains.name: Modern
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something modern--a word that describes something like a machine, system, or country that uses the most recent equipment, ideas, and methods.

subdomains.name: Old fashioned
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something old fashioned--something that was done or used in the past, but not done or used now.

subdomains.name: Once
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening once.

subdomains.name: Again
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening again or doing something again.

subdomains.name: Sometimes
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening sometimes.

subdomains.name: Often
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening often--happening or done many times.

subdomains.name: All the time
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening all the time.

subdomains.name: Every time
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to something happening every time something else happens.

subdomains.name: Never
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that something that never happens, or that something has not once happened.

subdomains.name: Continue, persevere
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to continuing to do something.

subdomains.name: Interrupt
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to interrupting someone--speaking when someone is speaking, or doing something to stop someone from doing what they are doing.

subdomains.name: Start again
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to starting to do something after stopping for some time.

subdomains.name: Interval
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to an interval between two events.

subdomains.name: Speed
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the speed at which a person acts or the speed at which something happens.

subdomains.name: Quick
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to doing something at a quick speed or something happening quickly.

subdomains.name: Slow
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to doing something at a slow speed.

subdomains.name: Sudden
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a sudden event--something happens that I don't expect.

subdomains.name: Location
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to the place where something is located and for words indicating the location of something.

subdomains.name: Here, there
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to a place in relation to the speaker or listener.

subdomains.name: In front of
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to being in front of you.

subdomains.name: Behind
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is behind you.

subdomains.name: Beside
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that something is to the side of someone.

subdomains.name: Around
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is around something else.

subdomains.name: Between
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is between two other things.

subdomains.name: On
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is on another thing.

subdomains.name: Above
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something is above another thing. The concept 'above' is inherently relational, expressing the relative positions of two things.

subdomains.name: Under, below
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something is under another thing. The concept 'under' is inherently relational, expressing the relative positions of two things.

subdomains.name: Inside
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is outside something else.

subdomains.name: Out, outside
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is outside of another thing.

subdomains.name: Touching, contact
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that two things are touching or in contact with each other.

subdomains.name: Next to
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is next to something else.

subdomains.name: Across
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to a place on another side of something from the reference point. 'Across' involves three things--the object, the reference point, and something else in between the two.

subdomains.name: Indefinite location
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is at an indefinite location.

subdomains.name: Direction
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to a direction.

subdomains.name: Forward
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a forward direction.

subdomains.name: Backward
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a backward direction.

subdomains.name: Right, left
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to right and left.

subdomains.name: Up
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the direction up.

subdomains.name: Down
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the direction down.

subdomains.name: Away from
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a direction away from something.

subdomains.name: Towards
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a direction toward something.

subdomains.name: North, south, east, west
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the directions of the compass.

subdomains.name: Be at a place
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being at a place.

subdomains.name: Absent
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being absent--to not be in a particular place, or not be in the correct or expected place.

subdomains.name: Area
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to an area.

subdomains.name: Vicinity
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to a vicinity--an area around something else.

subdomains.name: Occupy an area
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to occupying an area.

subdomains.name: Space, room
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the amount of empty space that is available to be used.

subdomains.name: Interval, space
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to an interval or space between things.

subdomains.name: Spatial relations
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate a spatial relation between situations.

subdomains.name: Contain
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something contains something.

subdomains.name: Parts of things
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to a part of something. These words are often based on the parts of a person's body.

subdomains.name: Front
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the front part of something.

subdomains.name: Back
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the back part of something.

subdomains.name: Top
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the top part of something.

subdomains.name: Bottom
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the bottom part of something.

subdomains.name: Side
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the side part of something.

subdomains.name: Inner part
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the inside part of something.

subdomains.name: Outer part
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the outside or surface part of something.

subdomains.name: Middle
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the middle part or center of something.

subdomains.name: Edge
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the edge of something--the part of something where two sides come together.

subdomains.name: End, point
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the end of something.

name: Grammar
description: Use this domain for technical linguistic terms that refer to grammatical words and constructions. Most languages have few if any words in this domain.

subdomains.name: General words
subdomains.description: Use the following section for words that don't belong in any other domain because they are so general in meaning that you can use them to talk about any topic. Use this domain for general and indefinite words that can be used in the place of any word. Some languages have a general word that can replace a noun or a verb. For instance some Philippine languages use the word 'kwan' in this way. Colloquial German can use the word 'dings' as a noun or verb. Often these words are used when you can't remember the particular word you are trying to think of. In English we use the word 'blank' when we don't want to say a word, for instance when we are testing someone and want them to say the word.

subdomains.name: Be
subdomains.description: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'be' may be used to identify something, describe something, and many other ideas.

subdomains.name: Exist
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something exists.

subdomains.name: Become, change state
subdomains.description: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of change of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'become' may be used to a change in identity, a change in characteristic, a change in nature, and many other ideas.

subdomains.name: Have, of
subdomains.description: Many languages have several general words that are used to indicate a variety of relationships between two things. There are three such words in English: "have," "of," and the possessive suffix "-'s." The basic meaning of these words in English is 'to own', but they can mean many other things too. For instance they can mean that I am related to someone (I have a brother), something has a part (birds have wings), and many other ideas. There is also a set of pronouns in English that are like nouns ending in -'s (my/mine, your/yours, his, her/hers, its, our/ours, their/theirs, whose). Use this domain for these general words.

subdomains.name: Attribution
subdomains.description: Attributes often belong to a class of attributes (shape = straight, curved) or to a scale (length = long, short). The class or scale can sometimes be included in the expression, but does not mark the proposition itself. (The towel <feels> damp. The box <weighs> five kilos.)

subdomains.name: Do
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general verbs with a volitional subject (agent).

subdomains.name: Happen
subdomains.description: Use this domain for non-volitional pro-verbs.

subdomains.name: React, respond
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to reacting or responding to something.

subdomains.name: Create
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to creating something--causing something to be that did not exist before.

subdomains.name: Design
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to designing something--to decide and plan how something new will look and work.

subdomains.name: Make
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to making something--joining things together to create something to be that did not exist before.

subdomains.name: Change something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to someone changing something.

subdomains.name: Event propositions
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate event propositions. Event propositions are similar in that they are normally expressed by a subject and a verb, possibly including an object, indirect object, or complement clause. However there are multiple ways in which a language can express an event, such as a passive construction, noun phrase, or subordinate clause. In addition each event type is different in its primary cases, and in the ways those cases are marked. Each event type has subtypes, such as intransitive, transitive, and bitransitive verbs. A great deal of research is needed in order to identify all the variations. Ultimately every verb must be investigated to determine how it behaves in each syntactic construction and how its case relations are marked. No two verbs are entirely alike.

subdomains.name: Thing
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to things.

subdomains.name: Physical, non-physical
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something that is physical--that you can touch and see, and for words describing something that is non-physical--that you cannot touch or see.

subdomains.name: Situation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a situation--a particular time and place, and the things that are true about it.

subdomains.name: General adjectives
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general adjectives that can replace or stand for a specific adjective.

subdomains.name: General adverbs
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general adverbs that can replace or stand for other adverbs.

subdomains.name: Part of speech
subdomains.description: This domain is for organization purposes and should not be used for any words. Use the domains in this section for words that belong to a particular part of speech. It is best not to use these domains, since they are based on grammar and not meaning. But if you have a small group of words that belong to a part of speech and you want to list them all, you can use these domains. You can also classify words in this section if you don't know what they mean yet.

subdomains.name: Adjectives
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all adjectives. If there are many adjectives in your language, you should not try to list them all here. If you want to find all the adjectives, most dictionary programs can sort your dictionary by part of speech. However if your language only has a few adjectives, you can list them all in this domain. In the book, "Where Have All the Adjectives Gone?" R. M. W. Dixon [Dixon, R. M. W. 1982. Where have all the adjectives gone? Berlin: Mouton.] identifies seven universal semantic types that are often expressed by adjectives. They are: Age (new, young, old), Dimension (big, little, long, short, wide, narrow, thick, fat, thin), Value (good, bad, proper, perfect, excellent, fine, delicious, atrocious, poor), Color (black, white, red), Human propensity (jealous, happy, kind, clever, generous, cruel, rude, proud, wicked), Physical property (hard, soft, heavy, light, rough, smooth, hot, cold, sweet, sour), Speed (fast, slow). Words in the Human propensity class may be nouns. Words in the Physical property and Speed classes may be verbs.

subdomains.name: Adverbs
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all adverbs. If there are many adverbs in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.

subdomains.name: Pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the personal pronouns, including independent, subject, object, and possessive pronouns. It is best to collect all the pronouns in a chart. This way you are more certain of collecting them all and seeing how they are related to each other. A language may have more sets and more distinctions than English does, or it may have less. For instance some languages have a pronoun 'we' which includes the hearer, and another pronoun 'we' which excludes the hearer. Other languages have an indefinite pronoun that means something like the English word 'someone'. Many languages do not have the masculine (he), feminine (she), and neuter (it) distinctions that English has. It is necessary to determine the sets and functions of the pronouns for each language.

subdomains.name: Reflexive pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns that refer back to the subject of the sentence. These pronouns should be added to the chart of personal pronouns.

subdomains.name: Indefinite pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns that do not refer to a definite person or thing, but can refer to anyone or anything. Some languages will not have all the sets of pronouns described below. Add each set you find in your language to the pronoun chart.

subdomains.name: Relative pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns used in relative clauses.

subdomains.name: Question words
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns used in questions.

subdomains.name: Demonstrative pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for demonstrative pronouns.

subdomains.name: Personally
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that someone does something himself, rather than through someone else.

subdomains.name: Prepositions, postpositions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all prepositions and postpositions.

subdomains.name: Conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all conjunctions.

subdomains.name: Phrase conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all phrase level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two words within a phrase.

subdomains.name: Clause conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all clause level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two clauses.

subdomains.name: Sentence conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all sentence level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two sentences.

subdomains.name: Particles
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all particles.

subdomains.name: Classifiers
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all classifiers.

subdomains.name: Interjections
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all interjections.

subdomains.name: Idiophones
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all idiophones. If there are many idiophones in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.

subdomains.name: Affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all affixes that do not fit in any of the subdomains under it. This section should be filled out by a linguist.

subdomains.name: Verb affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all verb affixes.

subdomains.name: Noun affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all noun affixes.

subdomains.name: Derivational affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all derivational affixes. A derivational affix is joined to a root and changes it into a different word. Derivational affixes often change the root into a different part of speech. Adding a derivational affix usually changes the meaning of the root in a significant way.

subdomains.name: Very
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that intensify an attribute.

subdomains.name: Degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate a degree on a scale.

subdomains.name: To a large degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a large degree.

subdomains.name: To a small degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a small degree.

subdomains.name: To a larger degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a larger degree.

subdomains.name: To a smaller degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a smaller degree.

subdomains.name: Completely
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

subdomains.name: Partly
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.

subdomains.name: Do intensely
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating intensity of an action.

subdomains.name: Attribution of an attribute
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that modify an attribute.

subdomains.name: Semantic constituents related to verbs
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that modify verbs.

subdomains.name: Tense and aspect
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense and aspect.

subdomains.name: Tense
subdomains.description: Use this domain for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense (also known as temporal deixis)--the time of a situation (event, activity, or state) in relation to a reference point, which is usually the time of utterance. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Aspect--dynamic verbs
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of dynamic verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Aspect--stative verbs
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of stative verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Relational tenses
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate relational tenses. Relational tenses describe situations where the reference time is not the same as the moment of speech. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Agent-oriented modalities
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate agent-oriented modalities. Agent-oriented modalities describe internal or external conditions on a willful agent with respect to the completion of the predicate situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Can
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that someone can do something.

subdomains.name: Can't
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being incapable of doing something.

subdomains.name: Necessary
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something must happen.

subdomains.name: Moods
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate moods.

subdomains.name: Imperative
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate imperatives. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press. Use this domain for words and affixes that a speaker uses to indicate that he is making a command. English has no command word. Some languages change the form of the verb by adding an affix. Some languages have special verbs that are only or normally used as commands. Those verbs could be classified here.

subdomains.name: Hortative
subdomains.description: Use this domain for ways of saying that someone should do something. If I say someone should do something, I think it is good that he does it.

subdomains.name: Interrogative
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he is asking a question. English has no question word, but other languages such as Japanese do.

subdomains.name: Epistemic moods
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate epistemic moods. Epistemic moods have the whole proposition in their scope and indicate the degree of commitment of the speaker to the truth or future truth of the proposition. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Certainly, definitely
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is certainly true or is certain to happen.

subdomains.name: Sure
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being sure that something is true.

subdomains.name: Probably
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is probable or likely to occur.

subdomains.name: Possible
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is possible. Maybe implies that the speaker doesn't know something.

subdomains.name: Uncertain
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that no one is certain that something is true, or when it is impossible to be certain that something is true.

subdomains.name: Unsure
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to not feeling sure about something or someone.

subdomains.name: Think so
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that you think something is true, but you are not completely sure about it.

subdomains.name: Maybe
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks it is possible that something may happen or be true, but he isn't certain.

subdomains.name: Seem
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something seems to be a certain way--you see (or hear) something and think something about it, but you are not sure that what you think is true.

subdomains.name: Just, almost not
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that although something is true, it almost is not true.

subdomains.name: Don't think so, doubt it
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that you think something is unlikely to be true or to happen.

subdomains.name: Impossible
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is impossible.

subdomains.name: Evidentials
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate evidentials. An evidential is when the speaker indicates the source of the information on which an assertion about a situation is based. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Evaluator
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating who is evaluating the proposition.

subdomains.name: Yes
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that affirm or agree with the truth of something, or that answer a yes/no question in the affirmative.

subdomains.name: No, not
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that negate or deny the truth of something, or that answer a yes/no question in the negative.

subdomains.name: Markers expecting an affirmative answer
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that an affirmative answer is expected to a question.

subdomains.name: Markers expecting a negative answer
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that a negative answer is expected to a question.

subdomains.name: Subordinating particles
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate a subordinate clause. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Adverbial clauses
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate adverbial clauses. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Case
subdomains.description: Each verb has a set of semantic case relations. For instance in the sentence 'I gave flowers to my wife' the verb give has three case relations. 'I' is the Agent, 'flowers' is the Patient, and 'my wife is the 'Recipient'. In this sentence the only word that marks a case relation is 'to'. English often marks case relations by their position in the sentence. Some languages mark case relations by affixes, prepositions, postpositions, and sometimes special verbs. To completely describe a language, each verb must be investigated, all its case relations must be identified, and all the ways in which these relations are marked must be described. Since verbs are often unique and unpredictable in their case relations, this information should go into the dictionary. This section should be used to classify the words and affixes that are used to mark case relations. This domain should be used for technical terms that refer to case.

subdomains.name: Primary cases
subdomains.description: Use this section for primary cases.

subdomains.name: Beneficiary of an event
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the beneficiary of an event. The sentence "John built a house for his father" is ambiguous. If the house was for his father to live in, then "for" would mark the 'Beneficiary of a patient', meaning that the house was for the father. If, on the other hand, the father was intending to build the house to sell, but couldn't due to an injury, then "for" would mark the 'Beneficiary of an event', meaning the father benefited from the building of the house.

subdomains.name: Instrument
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark an instrument used to do something.

subdomains.name: Means
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the means by which something is done.

subdomains.name: Way, manner
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the way or manner in which something is done.

subdomains.name: Attendant circumstances
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the attendant circumstances in which something happened.

subdomains.name: Spatial location of an event
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the spatial location of an event.

subdomains.name: Source (of movement)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the Source (original location) of something.

subdomains.name: Path (of movement)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the Path of movement.

subdomains.name: Goal (of movement)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the Goal of movement.

subdomains.name: Origin (of a person)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the place where someone was born or the place where they have been living.

subdomains.name: Semantically similar events
subdomains.description: Use this section for words that join semantically similar events into one sentence. Each sentence is actually reporting two or more situations, which may differ in one or two respects. The words to be included in these domains indicate that two situations are being reported, or mark the differences between the two situations.

subdomains.name: Together
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating when two or more people each do the same thing and do it together, or when they do it separately.

subdomains.name: With, be with
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a person who accompanied the subject of a proposition.

subdomains.name: With, do with someone
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a person who does something with another person who is the subject of the sentence.

subdomains.name: Each other
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that two or more people do something to each other.

subdomains.name: In groups
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that the subjects of a clause do something in groups.

subdomains.name: Patient-related cases
subdomains.description: Use this section for cases that bear a relationship to the 'Patient' of a proposition.

subdomains.name: Beneficiary (of a patient)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the beneficiary of the Patient of an activity. The Patient is often expressed as the object of a sentence. In the sentence "John built a house for his parents," the house is the Patient. It is the house that benefits the parents, not the building of the house.

subdomains.name: Recipient (of a patient)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the recipient of the Patient of an activity. The Patient is usually expressed as the object of a sentence.

subdomains.name: With (a patient)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark a second Patient that accompanies the primary Patient of an activity. In this type of sentence there are actually two Patients, but one of them has more prominence than the other. The primary patient is usually expressed as the object of the sentence. The second Patient may be marked by an oblique case or preposition/postposition. For instance it may be conceived as accompanying the first Patient.

subdomains.name: Connected with, related
subdomains.description: Use the domains in this section for words that indicate a logical relation between two or more words or sentences. Use this domain for words that indicate an unspecified logical relation between people, things, or situations.

subdomains.name: Coordinate relations
subdomains.description: Use this section for words indicating coordinate relations. Do not put any words in this domain. It is only for organizational purposes.

subdomains.name: And, also
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that you are adding another thought to a previous thought. Words in this domain may indicate a variety of relationships between words, phrases, clauses, or sentences. For instance the words may join two clauses that are the same except that the subjects are different, or the objects are different, or the verbs are different.

subdomains.name: Or, either
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating an alternative relation between two things or propositions.

subdomains.name: Association
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating an association between two things.

subdomains.name: Combinative relation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a combinative relation between two things.

subdomains.name: But
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a contrast between two thoughts that are different in some way.

subdomains.name: Except
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is an exception to a group, rule or pattern--something is true of all the things (or people) in a group, but it is not true of one thing.

subdomains.name: Instead
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is true of one thing (or person) instead of another thing.

subdomains.name: Dissociation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a dissociation relation between two things or propositions.

subdomains.name: Distribution
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that an event is distributed throughout a group, area, or time span.

subdomains.name: Equivalence
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating equivalence between two things or propositions.

subdomains.name: Dependency relations
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is dependent on another thing.

subdomains.name: Derivation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something derives from another thing.

subdomains.name: Limitation of topic
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the topic that is being talked about.

subdomains.name: In general
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is generally true, but not true in every case.

subdomains.name: Relations involving correspondences
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating relations involving correspondences--a situation in which one thing is the same or similar in some respect to something else.

subdomains.name: Basis
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is the basis for another thing.

subdomains.name: Cause
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that someone or something is the cause for an event or state, that one event is the cause for another event or state, or that an event or state is reasonable (having sufficient cause). For instance in the sentence, "John caused David to fall," "John caused" is an enabling proposition that brings about the primary proposition "David fell."

subdomains.name: Reason
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that reason why someone does something.

subdomains.name: Without cause
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that an event or state has no cause or reason, or is unreasonable (has insufficient cause).

subdomains.name: Result
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is the result of another thing.

subdomains.name: Without result
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something had no result.

subdomains.name: Purpose
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something was done for the purpose of another thing happening.

subdomains.name: Without purpose
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something had no purpose.

subdomains.name: Condition
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate a clause in a conditional sentence (If this is true, then that is true). The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.

subdomains.name: Concession
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that the speaker is conceding a point in a debate.

subdomains.name: Discourse markers
subdomains.description: Use this domain for conjunctions and particles that function on the discourse level, and whose meaning and function is uncertain.

subdomains.name: Markers of transition
subdomains.description: Use this domain for conjunctions that simply move the discourse forward without any specific relationship indicated between what comes before and what comes after.

subdomains.name: Markers of emphasis
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that the phrase or sentence is particularly important.

subdomains.name: Prompters of attention
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that are used to get someone's attention or direct the listener's attention to something. These may use a verb meaning 'look' or 'listen'. Some may be a word specifically referring to attention. Others may be a greeting. Others may be words that refer to non-verbal communication such as clearing your throat.

subdomains.name: Markers of direct address
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that the speaker uses to refer to the person he is addressing. These words are usually used when you start talking to someone, but can be used during a speech or conversation to refer to the person you are talking to.

subdomains.name: Markers of identificational and explanatory clauses
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that begin a clause that identifies a specific case or example of what has just been said, or that explains what has just been said. Specific case: I have just mentioned a general class of things or a general idea and want to give a specific example of what I am talking about. Explanation: I have just said something and I think people might misunderstand, so I want to explain what I mean. Digression: I am talking about a particular topic, but want to say something that does not fit into my topic, so I say something that is about a different topic.

subdomains.name: Markers of focus
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that one of several things is in focus.

subdomains.name: Hesitation fillers
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses when he hesitates or pauses while he is speaking in order to think about what he is saying.

subdomains.name: Honorifics
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that the speaker uses to show respect or a lack of respect to the person he is addressing. Some languages have elaborate systems of honorifics. Other languages have none. Languages with a stratified social structure often use honorifics. Egalitarian societies generally lack them, but some egalitarian societies may use them. For instance in Nahuatl there are four levels of honorifics. Level 1 is how one addresses intimates, small children, and pets. Level 2 is for strangers and persons treated formally. Level 3 is for respected persons, the dead, and God. Level 4 is for obsequious respect, as for the archbishop in an interview with a priest, and for ritual kin. (Jane H. Hill and Kenneth C. Hill. 1978. Honorific usage in modern Nahuatl: the expression of social distance and respect in the Nahuatl of the Malinche Volcano area, Language 54:123-155.) In Japanese, which has a stratified social structure, a person uses one set of words and affixes when speaking to someone below you in the social hierarchy, such as your wife, children, and pets. A different set of words is used when speaking to peers. Another set is used when speaking to a superior. A fourth set is used when speaking to the emperor. English used to have two pronouns for second person singular. 'Thou' was used for equals and inferiors, and 'you' was used for superiors. Your language may have special honorific words used as (1) pronouns, (2) affixes, (3) particles, (4) terms of direct address, (5) greetings (6) requests, (7) apologies.

subdomains.name: Name
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to proper nouns--the name given to a particular person or thing to distinguish it from other things like it. Proper nouns are often not included in a dictionary, or are included in an appendix at the front or back of a dictionary. This is because there are so many of them, they are sometimes difficult to define, and it saves space in the dictionary. For instance place names can be included in a map. So it might be good to type the proper nouns into a special file.

subdomains.name: Name of a person
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the name of a person. Each culture has a system of personal names to identify individuals and kin groups. The subcategories under this heading should reflect the cultural system. If your language has a special set of names that do not fit any of they domains given here, then set up a special domain.

subdomains.name: Personal names
subdomains.description: Use this domain for those names that are given to people, that people use to call to each other and to talk about each other.

subdomains.name: Family names
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the families that exist within the language community. If your culture does not use family names, just leave this domain empty.

subdomains.name: Clan names
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the clans that exist within the language community. The distinction between family, clan, tribe, and nation is based on politics and emotion. Our purpose here is not to make political statements, but merely to list the names. There may be no distinction between family and clan, in which case ignore this domain and use the domain 'Family names'.

subdomains.name: Tribal names
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the tribes that exist around the language community, including the name of your own tribe. These tribal names may or may not correspond with the names of countries.

subdomains.name: Names of languages
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the languages that are spoken in the area around the language community, including the name of your own language. These language names may or may not correspond with the names of countries. Do not try to include every language name in the world, only the neighboring and important ones. For instance you might want to include the languages that border your own and the national language. Give the form that you use. For instance the German people call their language 'Deutsch', but in English we call it 'German'.

subdomains.name: Nickname
subdomains.description: Use this domain for common nicknames--an additional name given to a person later in life, often descriptive. Also include general names used to call or refer to someone when you don't know their name

subdomains.name: Terms of endearment
subdomains.description: Use this domain for terms of endearment--a name used by lovers or spouses to express love or intimacy. Some languages may have special names used by close friends.

subdomains.name: Name of a place
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the name of a place.

subdomains.name: Names of countries
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the countries that exist around the language community, especially those countries where your language is spoken. Include the name of your own country. Do not list every country in the world, unless your language has developed special names or pronunciations for those countries. Include any country that you refer to in your language, especially those names whose pronunciation you have adapted to fit your language. Give the form of the name that you use, rather than the official spelling. For instance the Japanese refer to their country as 'Nihon', but in English will call it 'Japan'. So 'Japan' is an English word and should go into an English dictionary. But 'Nihon' is not an English word and should not go in the dictionary.

subdomains.name: Names of regions
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the regions within your country or language area. Some of these may be political regions. Others may be informal terms. Give the local pronunciation, rather than some foreign spelling. You may want to limit this domain to just those areas within your language area. However if you have special names for areas outside of your language area, for example 'the Mideast', you should include them.

subdomains.name: Names of cities
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of cities, towns, and villages in the language area. Include the names of important cities outside of the language area if your language has a special name for the city or a different pronunciation for it. It might be good to use a map for this. In fact it is good to include a map of the language area in a published dictionary. If your language area is very large, there may be hundreds or thousands of cities, towns, and villages. In this case you will have to decide which should be included in the dictionary. Or you could decided to list them in a special section.

subdomains.name: Names of streets
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of highways, roads, streets, and trails in the language area. If there are many such names, only include the important names (e.g. King's Highway) or commonly used names (e.g. Main Street).

subdomains.name: Names of heavenly bodies
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the heavenly bodies.

subdomains.name: Names of continents
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the continents. Only include the names of continents if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

subdomains.name: Names of mountains
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the mountains in the language area. Only include the names of mountains outside the language area if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

subdomains.name: Names of oceans and lakes
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the oceans and lakes in the language area. Only include the names of oceans and lakes outside the language area if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

subdomains.name: Names of rivers
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the proper names of the rivers in the language area. Only include the names of rivers outside the language area if your language has borrowed or adapted the name and you talk about them in your language.

subdomains.name: Name of a thing
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the name of a thing. Many cultures give names to particular buildings, ships, airplanes, organizations, companies, schools, and other things. If your language has hundreds of names for some kind of thing, it is best to not try to list them all. But if there are a few important names for one kind of thing, set up a domain for them.

subdomains.name: Names of animals
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the name of an animal. Some cultures give names to domesticated animals or to animals in stories. Think through each kind of domesticated animal.

subdomains.name: Names of buildings
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the name of a building.
